text:
Students who come to
Harvard Business School

not only have access to
world-renowned faculty

and facilities, but
a direct connection

to the vast biotech and life
science community of Boston

that is literally
second to none.

Our findings provide insight
into how our health care

system might be able
to draw upon a broader

range of providers to ensure
that access to quality care

is maintained for those
who otherwise would face

substantial clinical, social, or
economic barriers to treatment.

And the hope is that
for the first time,

we might be able to talk
about curing disease and not
just treating it.

Health care is
increasingly delivered
by teams of professionals.

But most physicians
are still paid

on the basis of individual
performance measures,

heavily anchored to volumes
of services rendered,

with very little weight
assigned to quality.

We know that
deductibles and co-pays
help reduce health care costs.

But when patients
cut back on care,

they're not just
cutting back on waste,

but missing out on care
where we know that treatment
makes a difference.

People often fail to engage
in healthy behaviors.

We can help people follow
through on these behaviors

and live healthier lives
if we help them turn
those behaviors into habits.

The Health Care
Initiative's mission

is to educate the
leaders of tomorrow

who will innovate, inspire, and
improve health care for all.
